reasoning:
First off, streaming video services like Netflix fall outside my circle of competence. I’ve spent my career investing in businesses I thoroughly understand—consumer staples, railroads, insurance—and Netflix is essentially a high-content, high-tech platform with capital-intensive content spending. That said, even by general standards Netflix’s competitive moat looks thin. It has some scale in subscriber numbers, but intense competition from Disney, Amazon, and Apple means customers can—and will—jump ship on a price hike. There’s no enduring pricing power in a market teeming with alternatives.

On management and capital allocation, I see a company levering up with a debt-to-equity ratio north of 4.3 and producing negligible owner earnings. Borrowing to fund original programming is no sin if it generates consistent free cash flow, but Netflix’s owner earnings are negative and management pays no dividend or repurchases stock—hardly a sign they’re thinking like owners. Financially, a 1.1% ROE, erratic earnings growth down 82% over ten periods, and unreported current ratio are red flags. The only bright spot is book value growth at 16% CAGR, but that masks cash burn on the content front.

Valuation is the final straw. A DCF spits out a negative intrinsic value and a negative margin of safety—meaning you’re paying for losses, not earnings. I’d rather own a wonderful business at a fair price than Netflix at any price. Long-term prospects hinge on endless content arms races and subscriber churn, not durable moats or dependable cash flows. Compared to Coca-Cola, Apple, or BNSF, Netflix simply doesn’t offer the predictability or margin of safety I demand. In short, I’ll pass.

fundamental_analysis.details: Weak ROE of 1.1%; High debt to equity ratio of 4.3; Strong operating margins; Current ratio data not available

consistency_analysis.details: Inconsistent earnings growth pattern; Total earnings growth of -82.4% over past 10 periods

moat_analysis.details: Good ROE performance: 6/10 periods >15%; Decent operating margins (avg: 35.4%) suggest some competitive advantage

book_value_analysis.details: Consistent book value per share growth (Buffett's favorite metric); Excellent book value CAGR: 16.1%

management_analysis.details: No significant new stock issuance detected; No or minimal dividends paid

details: Using three-stage DCF: Stage 1 (-3.5%, 5y), Stage 2 (-1.7%, 5y), Terminal (2.5%)
